review.body: A nice tear-jerker romance. Thayne always writes well, and her characters are believable.
this was very good. the relationship and tension was emotional.

Wouldn't know

I never once opened this book. You know how it goes in college. My professor required it and we never used it
I officially LOVE the dempseys . this was such a fun book with so many twists .

The book in the movie are both quite good.
Irish girl comes to Brooklyn in about 1950.

War has come, bringing with it massive destruction, death and taken its toll on the Nightside and its residents. There's no escape from this problem, no way to bluff past Lilith, until John works one final trick, bringing his life and the story full circle.

Great way to end the overreaching arc,...
It was okay, certainly not fantastic.

I enjoyed the book. Emaline learns that not everything is going to be perfect and to accept changes. As she has a chaotic summer, she's going into college at East U. I recommend this to any girl who is learning about life and changes and how to deal with them.
Very fun.

A Joyfully Jay review.

4 stars

Deep was a wonderful novella that I really wanted more of right from the start. The world building is somewhat limited, but the author has done a good job of describing the otherworldliness of the oceanic space that surrounds the Ariel. Mining the ocean of the moon T...
loved it . funny, romantic .. played with all of my emotions and totally had me wrapped in it . made me start to read all of the authors books .

book.title: To All the Boys I've Loved Before (To All the Boys I've Loved Before, #1)
book.publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers

review.body: I loved this book so much. It showed how painful high school drama can be, but how eventually you can get over it. Life can be slightly difficult when you are a teenager. Lara Jean shows a good example of how to deal with it well.

book.title: Mrs. Frisby and the Rats of NIMH (Rats of NIMH, #1)

review.body: G and I both loved this, but want to know which rat it was who died at the end.
I really enjoyed this book, even though I have no memory or knowledge of the Shakespeare play it mirrors. Christopher Moore is definitely an author I'll seek more of.

book.title: Mystery: Grave Danger - Part One: (Mystery, Suspense, Thriller, Suspense Crime Thriller) (( Suspense Thriller Mystery Novel Private Investigate Police collection))

review.body:
Thriller mystery

Intriguing story pulls you in from the start. Interesting characters lead the story through the action. Greatly enjoyed setup, anxious for more.

book.title: Gang Heat: The Stewardess (Unprotected Force Book 2)

review.body: I received this for a honest review. Nadia Nightside always does such an amazing job, though I do have to wonder about my insanity when it comes to reading her books at work. She is a type of author that you know right off the bat her her stories are going to start, hot and steamy. Yip bad idea o...

review.body:
*Slight Spoilers*

This was an ok read. It wasn't what I was expecting. I've been reading this series from the beginning. And I have to say... I'm 50/50 about it.

This book was a little bit on the serious side.
The pace of the book was kind of slow for me. I had a hard time connecting with Evren's ch...
I've heard that there's a new version of this out God Got a Dog that omits some of the poems, and I cannot fathom why. Read this one instead.

Book review
The Road
The Road, an eye opening fictional novel by Cormac McCarthy, that entrances the reader and exposes them to the harsh reality of mankind's darkest truths. The narrator tells the tale of a man and his young boy traveling are post apocalyptic blackened world overcoming hardships...

I didn’t realize this was the fourth book in a series until after I had requested it. Generally, though, I can pretty quickly get up to speed and not miss much overall. I think this book did a good job of that, and I didn’t feel like I missed much. The book was well-written, it was nice, quick re...
